content:
You might want to right click the message, but as you are already aware that is not an option. Perhaps use the filter log to view that information. it is accessed from the filter dialog along with edit etc. It can however be exceedingly slow to load into the dialog and may appear on first glance to be empty. That is because the filterlog.html file can be many megabytes in size (mine is 87MB) and Thunderbird can take many minutes to parse the entire log to load it. Generally it is much much faster to double click on the file in the profile folder and load it in Firefox.

Have a look at your message source. (Ctrl+U) to get the message ID, then search in the Firefox tab (ctrl+F) for the message id. You could also search on the subject, but there may be more than one message with that subject in the log. Multiple instances of the same email ID mean multiple filters hit that email.

This is an actual log entry from 4 years ago: 

[28-Feb-21, 11:51:13 AM] Applied filter "From is: mailer@lithium.com" to message from Mozilla Support Forum <no-reply@support.mozilla.org> - Thunderbird upload over IMAP aborts at 28-Feb-21, 11:41:47 AM moved message id = 01010177e6310344-895cb7e9-e813-480d-a727-f9d7db44bc2c-000000@us-west-2.amazonses.com to mailbox://nobody@Local%20Folders/Lists/Mozilla%20Thunderbird%20List
creator: MattAuSupport

First, my color scheme prevented the filter log from showing (it was white on white). Then, when I saw the filter listed, I still had to figure out which it was, because this filter wasn't named. (I wish the filter search let you search for the other attributes of the filters, not just the filter name.) Last but not least, when I clicked the "Mark it as solved" button in the email sent to me by Mozilla which included your response, I got a 405 error.

In any case, your reply helped me find a solution!

content: If you're looking to move your Outlook Express DBX files to Thunderbird, it's not too difficult, but there are a few steps. For new Thunderbird users, you can use the import wizard to directly transfer your emails, contacts, and settings. Just open Thunderbird, go to the "Import" option, select Outlook Express, and it should do the job. If you're already using Thunderbird, go to Tools > Import, choose "Mail," then select Outlook Express to bring everything over. However, the manual method can be a bit tricky, especially with large files, and you might lose some data or need to do things like contacts and emails separately. A smoother alternative is to convert your DBX files to PST, and then convert the PST files into MBOX format, which Thunderbird supports. This can help avoid issues and make the transfer easier.

content:
Serve che riporti esattamente i messaggi di errore che ricevi. Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)

content:
Hello there

To change the password is to go to Yahoo and change the password or not and update the password. Go back to Thunderbird and update that password there in Thunderbird s account settings. Yahoo uses the Oauth2 security protocol you can therefore use the app password generator for Thunderbird. So change your Yahoo password on that Yahoo website. Generate an app password for Thunderbird. Update your password in Thunderbird. Verify the changes by restarting Thunderbird.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/protect-your-thunderbird-passwords-primary-password#thunderbird:win11:tb128

Greetings google Thunderbird.
creator: Googlethunderbird.

content:
Yahoo uses the Oauth2 security protocol you can therefore use the app password generator for Thunderbird.

This is nonsense. Yahoo uses the Oauth2 authentication, hence there is no need for an app password. In fact app passwords are potentially less secure and should not be used when OAuth2 authentication is offered by the email provider.

Generate an app password for Thunderbird.

Once again, don't do that.

Go back to Thunderbird and update that password there in Thunderbird s account settings.

Thunderbird will prompt for the password when it's needed. Also, with OAuth2 authentication Thunderbird does not remember the actual account password, but an OAuth authentication token.

content:
I don't know why setting the preferences doesn't work, but there is another method using css: 

a:visited { color: red !important; }  a:link { color: green !important; }


Help/Troubleshooting Info, Profile Folder, Open Folder, close TB, create a new folder named chrome, create a new document in chrome with a text editor, name it userContent.css, Save as type: All files *.*, copy in the above code, change the colours as desired. Double-click toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets to true in Settings/General/Config. editor, restart TB.

Online css generator

video on how to create a css file (Firefox and TB)

See picture. This works in TB 128 and 139. Some html messages might contain styles that override the css.

I'm using beta 142.0b2 and the 'Links' underline settings is: Settings > General Scroll down to 'Reading & Display' There is a checkbox for 'Always underline links' which you select to enable or uncheck to disable.

content:
Non uso Mac e non ho idea di come funzioni il suo file system La posizione standard del profilo Thunderbird nei vari sistemi operativi è descritta qui -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird

Assicurati che nella colonna a destra sia selezionata l'esatta versione del sistema operativo e di Thunderbird che usavi. Il contenuto della pagina viene adattato in base a questa scelta.

Per un Mac generico e Thunderbird 115 le istruzioni sono queste:

Come aprire il proprio profilo senza avviare Thunderbird

  1. Fare clic sull'icona Finder nel dock. Sulla barra dei menu, fare clic sul menu Vai, tenere premuto il tasto option o alt e selezionare Libreria. Verrà aperta una finestra che contiene la cartella Libreria.
  2. Aprire la cartella "Thunderbird" e successivamente la cartella "Profiles". La cartella del profilo è all'interno di questa cartella.
  3. Aprire la cartella del profilo desiderato. Se si dispone di un unico profilo, la cartella corrispondente conterrà nella parte finale del nome il termine "default".

Ma probabilmente si riferiscono al sistema operativo funzionante non ad un backup.

content:
If the Thunderbird profile is specified as a UNC path, then you will be able to access files stored within that directory tree.

To access files outside the profile, you must set an exclusion by adding network hosts to hidden preference setting for mail.allowed_unc_hosts. For example hostname1,hostname2

content:
My guess is your tech friend installed from Microsoft, which puts everything in new places and limits your ability to get support on the forum. The official download at thunderbird.net installs app to c:\program files and the profile to the ...appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder. If you can uninstall and reinstall, then the standard process of copying should work. and, just for a refresher, here are normal steps:

Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content:
Follow these steps:

  1. locate the Local folders location. You can find that by clicking account settings and scrolling down to local folders and note the local directory on bottom line
  2. now, exit thunderbird and COPY that folder to another drive
  3. next, restart thunderbird and, on that Local Folders pane, click the dropdown menu on Local Directory, and point it to the new location. Thunderbird will probably close and restart
  4. now, check that all is working find with new layout
  5. you may now go to that original Local Folders location in the profile and delete the folders there.

content:
Yes, you can do that. Try this - it preserves your whole existing setup:

Install TB on the laptop, then start setting up the new profile:

- on the 'Set Up Your Existing Email Address' screen, enter name and email address only

- click the 'Configure manually' link

- scroll down and click 'Cancel' > Exit setup

Copy the TB files from the PC:

- launch Thunderbird on the PC

- go to Thunderbird menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information

- click the Application Basics > Profile Folder 'Open Folder' button

- the profile folder will open; navigate three levels up to the Roaming folder

- close TB, then copy the Thunderbird folder to a flash drive

Paste the TB files to the laptop:

- go to the new PC's Roaming folder as instructed above and delete the Thunderbird folder

- paste the Thunderbird folder from the flash drive to the laptop

- launch Thunderbird

content:
Thank you, Christ1. I had to remove a few things in the above post to make it less than 10000 characters. I took out a reference to English(CA) and English (GB) because I don't think those matter for this issue, and I took out a reference to calendar because I don't use that.

The "stored passwords" box has information for 5 of the 8 email accounts I retrieve from Gmail. The other three aren't shown there at all.

You can see that I have a different SMTP port number for the email account in question here - I saw someplace that it should be that number, so I tried changing it but that didn't help, either. I left it like that since it didn't make the problem worse.

I hope this helps you figure out if this can be fixed. Any ideas are appreciated. Laurie
creator: booksr4usagain

content:
All I get when it tries to retrieve messages from Gmail is a box to give my email, (just that, not a password) and then an error message that it won't work and there is no more information.

What is the exact error message?

You can see that I have a different SMTP port number for the email account in question here

I don't see any reason to use a different port no. for the outgoing server on account9, compared to the other 7 Gmail accounts. But this isn't your problem.

Make sure cookies are allowed in Thunderbird during the authentication. Also see https://support.mozilla.org/kb/automatic-conversion-google-mail-accounts-oauth20

Do not use a VPN during authentication.

Are you running some sort of software like a local web server, which is blocking TCP port 80 on localhost? If so, shut it down for the authentication.
creator: christ1

content:
Thank you!

I changed the port back to the default, and allowed cookies for sites visited, and it worked.

I'm so excited that now I can change these old Gmail passwords and still grab those emails in Thunderbird. Some of those passwords have not been changed since 2012 or earlier, so I really want to do that in light of all the reports of hacking and such.

I'm so grateful to you. Have a WONDERFUL day!
creator: booksr4usagain

content: You're welcome. When your problem has been fixed can you mark the topic as 'Solved' please? Thank you.
creator: christ1

content: My guess is that you have both maine.rr accounts trying to use the same SMTP server. You can check that by clicking 'account settings' and scrolling down to 'Outgoing servers SMTP' and clicking the link. You should see five SMTP server settings, one for each account. For the two for maine.rr, change the DESCRIPTION field to contain the full email address for the accounts. THEN, click account settings , then click the account name in left side and then look at bottom line in right pane. you should see the email address for that account in the outgoing server field. if not, click the dropdown there and select the proper one.
creator: davidsk

content: David, this 84 yr old, poor tech savvy citizen with bad memory retention thanks you for reply & help. Not sure all the info requested at "change the DESCRIPTION" as to exactly what the full email addresses included. Did note that the Google accounts used "smtp" and the RoadRunner (RR) did not...and, if i needed to include my addresses. Did try adding "smtp" to the RR address, but not work and spent too much time changing back. Did go to the "THEN click account settings again and found at the "botttom line" that one Google account said "smtp.gmail.com (DEFAULT)...and, after looking at each email line it was the only one. I also looked at the "edit" tab for each address and all showed "default" on the "port:" line with the RR's showing port#587 and the Gmails showing port# 465. Looks to me that the Default is the problem, but do not know if undo is correct or how to do it. Any additional advice? Again, many thanks for your help and reply. Doug Erskine
creator: dougerskine

content:
The 2 maine.rr.com accounts are the ones not able to reply. They are: (1) derskine@maine.rr.com, and (2) dougerskine@maine.rr.com. Using "Account Settings" each line of the SMTP settings screen is the exact same for both addresses (users). Here is how they read under "Settings":

Description: RoadRunner/TWC Server Name: mail.twc.com Port: 587 (up/down arrow tabs here) Default: 587 Then under "Security & Authentication": Connection security: STARTTLS Authorization method: Normal password User Name: (the 2 accounts listed above)

The 3 Gmail accounts work fine, but noticed their "Outgoing SMTP Server" says "Google Mail - smtp.gmail.com (Default)" which when clicked the line at the top says "Use Different Server" and then has a line for all each of the 5 emails. Again, I muchly appreciate your help and follow up, adding it has become a bigger project than anticipated. Doug
creator: dougerskine

content:
For 'user name', are you using the full email address? That is, derskine@maine.rr.com and not just derskine. That is often a problem.

For description field, change to the affected email address not Roadrunner/TWC. That is just documentation, but you need the documentation field to be unique for ALL of the SMTP server settings. Then, from account pane, looking at the outgoing server link, the email address will be visible so you can be sure you're using the right SMTP server
creator: davidsk

content: Go to Account Settings > account name > Composition & Addressing > Composition and uncheck "Compose messages in HTML format"
creator: Mapenzi

content:
Try this - it preserves your whole existing setup from the laptop:

1. Launch Thunderbird on the old laptop

2. Go to Thunderbird menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information

3. Click the Application Basics > Profile Folder 'Open Folder' button

4. The profile folder will open; navigate three levels up to the Roaming folder

5. Close TB, then copy the Thunderbird folder to a flash drive

6. Go to the new laptop's Roaming folder as instructed above and delete the Thunderbird folder

7. Paste the Thunderbird folder from the flash drive to the new PC

8. Launch Thunderbird
creator: siffemoz

content: Thank you Ed. I appreciate your help so much!
creator: lorettac70

content:
Went to AOL and generated a new APP password

Why would you want to generate an app password in the first place? If you use OAuth2 authentication for both, the incoming, and outgoing server, then you don't need an app password. You have to use you main AOL account password. App passwords are considered less secure, and shouldn't be used anyway.

TB generated the saved password oauth://login.aol.com (mail-w).

This isn't a password, but an OAuth authentication token. You'll have to authenticate once with your main AOL account password though. The token will expire at some point, and you'll be prompted to re-authenticate.

To force re-authentication you can delete the authentication token listed in 'Saved Logins'. This can also help to fix authentication problems. For the OAuth authentication to succeed you'll have to temporarily allow cookies in Thunderbird.
creator: christ1

content:
Thank you Chris. I'm not a hi-tech person. I first edited the POP saved PW to the new APP PW--no success., but when I read the many replies on this forum, they told me to remove the two saved PW's. When I successfully sent a test message to myself, TB posted the saved output PW, part-of-which I showed. But there was no success in POP downloads [TB gave a timeout message]. I don't see why the install of 139.0.2 should cause that. 

I checked my settings and all cookies are allowed.

content: Thank you Christ1!! Now my POP is working with your POP server fix. What remains is this. The SAVED PASSWORDS only has the SMTP [send] OAUTH2 line, no POP line. And is it just a coincidence that AOL stopped allowing the pop.verizon.net that has worked for years, or did the update to 139.0.2 cause the problem? Any way it's now working, and if no other TB user has the problem then it's not a bug.
creator: lkint

content:
The SAVED PASSWORDS only has the SMTP [send] OAUTH2 line, no POP line.

Now you should have one line in 'Saved Logins' for your AOL account starting with 'oauth'. That's all you need. If you still have a line starting with 'smtp', you can remove it.

</blockquote> And is it just a coincidence that AOL stopped allowing the pop.verizon.net that has worked for years </blockquote>

I don't know. I'm surprised pop.verizon.net did work at all after the service was moved to AOL. And I don't think it's been a problem with the update to TB 139.0.2.
creator: christ1

content:
Hello there

Emails that are containing certain links to addresses that do not work at the moment while clicking on them within inbox mails I suppose that the browser settings aren’t oké to use or not updated ?at the moment?you can try to verify the selected browser for that pc system. Go to your system settings of that pc and look if for them if they are oké? Other look alike issues are there if you re latest Thunderbird version cannot open http or https and other links that where send into that inbox. That Thunderbird version might not know how to open that link again somehow to read it properly with that Thunderbird program. Turn on the pc system and go to Thunderbird. Go to preference / content / file types. Try to search for http or http s . You can configure it there by : Deleting the entry that is recent. And there also you select and choose to select for more browsers to work with. Be Sure that the Thunderbird version is downloaded from trusted download points.

Questions are open
creator: Googlethunderbird.

Hello there

Did some folders disappeared in that left pane? Or is it that just that saved emails as described did not where there after that mentioned update? Are you using IMAP or POP protocols? What anti virus do you use at the moment , can i ask?
creator: Googlethunderbird.

content:
Here's the setup that I've been using in Thunderbird:

That appears to be the information from the Yahoo support web site, but it's somewhat outdated.

Incoming Mail (IMAP) Server Server - export.imap.mail.yahoo.com

The incoming server should be imap.mail.yahoo.com.

The correct server settings for Yahoo are: Incoming server: imap.mail.yahoo.com, port 993, Connection security: SSL/TLS, Authentication method: OAuth2 Outgoing server: smtp.mail.yahoo.com, port 465, Connection security: SSL/TLS, Authentication method: OAuth2

Also see: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-yahoo#w_important-changes-to-authentication-method-notice

Note, as stated in the support article, for the OAuth authentication to succeed, you'll have to temporarily allow cookies in Thunderbird.
creator: christ1

content: On July 31, my email stopped sending and receiving on Thunderbird. I get no error messages. I see new email on my phone (not Thunderbird) so my server settings appear to be correct. I can send and receive from Android phone and iPad but not my laptop using Thunderbird. Again, no error message, just no activity since 11:25 am on the 31st.
creator: 280zxpilot
